attributes.comment:
RE: DHS Docket No. USCIS- 2006-0044

I feel that I have to comment on the proposed revisions to the USCIS fee
schedule. In reading over the proposed changes I noticed several points that
seem to me to be unfair to many of the applicants. They are namely:

1. US citizens should not be burdened with the cost of providing "FREE" services
to non-US citizens, those deemed unable to pay, or other exempt applicants.
This concept rewards people who have little or no resources at the cost of those
who do. I do not agree with the federal government assuming responsibility for
supporting people who cannot support themselves.

2. The document states that several fees have been merged together "so
applicants will pay a single fee rather than paying several fees". This leaves me to
assume that I may be forced to pay for services I do not want or need. When I go
to the grocery store I only pay for the things I want. Why should the USCIS fees
be any different?

3. As an adoptive parent I am already beaten down with regulations, fees, forms,
renewals (including renewal fees) and now increased fees. My wife and I are like
so many other adoptive families who desire to adopt a child from outside of the
US. We need to work with the USCIS to perform background checks on us and
also to provide citizenship for our adopted child.

I understand the need to recover costs, but please re-consider the allocation of the
fees. The proposed changes impose added burden on adoptive families who
intend to support their child, and give favor to persons who cannot support
themselves.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by David Gray
